qas.question: Who can translations of a sung text aid?
What type of familiar translation may be seen during an opera?
What do professional and amateur singers often sing?

answers.text: works in languages they do not know

qas.question: Translations help singers unfamiliar with a language do what?

answers.text: understand the meaning of the words they are singing.

qas.question: Who can translations of a sung text harm?
What type of familiar translation is restricted during an opera?

plausible_answers.text: works in languages they do not know

qas.question: What do professional and amateur singers never sing?

plausible_answers.text: understand the meaning of the words they are singing

qas.question: What do translations help singers familiar with a language do?
What kind of text is not allowed to have a translation?

context: Translations of <b8_0>sung texts<b8_0/>—whether of the above type meant to be sung or of a more or less literal type meant to be read—are also used as aids to <a0_0><b4_0>audiences, singers and conductors<b4_0/><a0_0/>, when a work is being sung in a language not known to them. The most familiar types are translations presented as <a1_0><b5_0>subtitles or surtitles<b5_0/><a1_0/> projected during opera performances, those inserted into concert programs, and those that accompany commercial audio CDs of vocal music. In addition, professional and amateur singers often sing <a2_0><b6_0>works in languages they do not know<b6_0/><a2_0/> (or do not know well), and translations are then used to enable them to <a3_0><b7_0>understand the meaning of the words they are singing<b7_0/>.
